6 Ways to Achieve New Things

Oct 29, 2020   By: Tilo Smith | #Goals  #Habits  #Inspiration  

Getting back on your horse, no matter how many times youâ€™ve fallen off.

Project Journal Bar

In my last post, I talked about the struggles and failures Iâ€™ve faced the past few years. Iâ€™ve been thinking about how to tackle my short-comings and problems to solve a single, relatively-simple issue thatâ€™s plagued me nearly my entire life: consistency in my work ethic.

There needs to be more hand-holding involved â€” change does not come quickly nor simply. So Iâ€™ve devised an entirely new project for myself: Journal Bar. This is a new blog that Iâ€™ve made where Iâ€™m going to be posting about the progress Iâ€™ve been making weekly. The (very simple) ingenious part is that Iâ€™m tracking the posts I write.

So, this is a sort of meta-accountability experiment. Having a goal thatâ€™s in charge of making sure I keep on-track with all of my other goals. The idea behind this is so simple that Iâ€™m kicking myself for not thinking about it sooner.

This idea and the progress Iâ€™ve made is very new, but I feel as though Iâ€™m going slowly enough to ensure that I donâ€™t fizzle out quickly and lose interest or energy for it. In addition to keeping track of my progress, Iâ€™ve also elected to use the blog as a space to write rough ideas that Iâ€™ll want to implement into articles later.

Going through the whole Beeminder process again opened my eyes to a few things that I believe will be helpful regarding perseverance with long-term results:

1. Be Anti-Circle

Itâ€™s said that the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again, but expecting different results. I was sifting through old text files on Dropbox, some all the way back from 2015 when I was back in high school, and I embarrassingly realized that there were certain goals there that I still had been writing down for 2020.

There are times where you need be ruthless and cut-throat with your dreams. There are certain large-scale ambitions that require so much time and energy that you wonâ€™t be able to balance them with other things, and theyâ€™ll be put on the backburner â€” over and over again. No matter how many times you tell yourself (or others) that youâ€™re going to start working on it soon, you never really get past the beginning stage.

Instead, look at what you are capable of, right now, with the abilities you have. Keep going with it, build upon what works. Make sure your to-do list isnâ€™t the same thing everyday, make sure your New Yearâ€™s resolutions arenâ€™t the same every year. If itâ€™s not working, do something different, donâ€™t run around in circles.

2. Eliminate Redundancy

The paradox of choice that we have regarding how exactly we keep track of ourselves and our goals can be crippling. There are certain notes I have on Dropbox, or on Google Drive, or just on my iPhone, or locally on my laptop.

This problem isnâ€™t eliminated if you switch to an analogue system either â€” you can have ideas and lists scattered between different planners, pocket notebooks, bullet journals, etc.

Itâ€™s easy to get caught up in using different software (particularly if itâ€™s mandated by school or work) and not notice that youâ€™re slowly creating a schism in your workflow.

Again, be ruthless and cut-throat, eliminate apps and notebooks that you donâ€™t really need to be using. Boil everything down to the bare essential, just one place that might not be perfect, but at least contains everything so you arenâ€™t repeating yourself or losing track.

3. Maintain Product Agnosticism

Itâ€™s easy to argue that one particular brand or program is superior in some fashion, but in the lightspeed world of venture capitalism, these companies and start-ups can disappear in an instance.

Donâ€™t allow yourself to get too comfortable using one particular thing. In fact, you should ideally using so5. Microreminders for Microgoalsmething thatâ€™s completely free, doesnâ€™t require internet access, and is stable. If something were to happen to the exclusive product youâ€™re using, it might take a toll on your morale, or even worse, you could lose data.

At the very least, have a simple, fail-safe system that you archive everything on. Whether it be a VCS repository, a USB drive, or a secondary laptop with a text editor.

4. Stack the Goodness

A simple solution to adding multiple new habits or daily tasks into your life is to build them upon things you already are doing very well and effortlessly. Such as taking the time you brush your teeth at night to think of everything youâ€™re grateful for thatâ€™s happened during the day.

A particularly good example with the current automated systems I have going is this: I track online courses I take (1) and upload the notes I write to a GitHub repository where I track my commits (2), and all of this is tracked as productive time on RescueTime (3). In a way, Iâ€™m keeping up three different good habits with a single action â€” self-directed learning.

5. Prioritize Passion over Tradition

One bad habit I realize I have is that, whenever I feel motivated to try to start working towards a positive progress again, I often do a Google search for â€œgood goals to keepâ€ or â€œgood habits to haveâ€, and Iâ€™ve started to realize this does more harm than good.

You shouldnâ€™t try to accomplish something simply because itâ€™s well-known to be a good thing to accomplish â€” like running a marathon. It will fail due to the lack of motivation behind it. Itâ€™s always far better to have a weird, unconventional goal that you find a genuine passion for deep down within. It doesnâ€™t matter what other people think about this, it never has.

6. Microreminders for Microgoals

My last suggestion is that the less time and energy something takes to do, then the less time and energy it should take for you to maintain it. It takes a lot of willpower and preparation to start something serious, like exercising three days a week â€” where you might need to have a community of support and journal weekly to remind yourself why itâ€™s important to keep up.

On the flip side, itâ€™s a lot easier to do something like start flossing after brushing your teeth, and there should be a smaller and less-intrusive reminder to yourself to do that so it doesnâ€™t feel like an overwhelming chore. Tasks in general are usually far less daunting than what we imagine they are, especially the longer with think about doing it than actually doing it.
